content.webTitle: Michael Owen warns Premier League clubs more fans could stage walkouts

fields.headline: Michael Owen warns Premier League clubs more fans could stage walkouts
fields.bodyText: Michael Owen has warned that supporters of other Premier League clubs could follow fans of Liverpool in staging organised walkouts from matches in protest against “extortionate” ticket prices. Jürgen Klopp has said Liverpool will heed “the sign” from supporters after around 10,000 left Anfield after 77 minutes of their 2-2 draw with Sunderland on Saturday, while the Football Supporters’ Federation is looking into how to respond to the failure of a scheme to cap away ticket prices at £20. But Owen, who scored 118 goals in 216 appearances for Liverpool between 1996 and 2004, believes supporters of other clubs will be eager to voice their frustration as well. “You’ve got to admire Liverpool fans for what they’re doing. There are other fans around the country who could be even more aggrieved,” he said. “I know at certain London clubs it’s nearly £100 for a ticket. It’s extortionate money to pay for a ticket. Ironically Liverpool are probably one of the cheaper tickets in the country, there are clubs who are culpable for charging through the roof to watch a game. “Football’s not a concert, your favourite band doesn’t come once a year and you watch it, for fans who have a real passion for the game it can be 50 games a season. You have a good cup run. The last place you want to be taking money from is your fans through ticket prices.” Owen added: “Full credit to them for standing up for what they believe in. It’s been a problem for a long time, people have been complaining about it for a long time. Now it’s probably the first time people have started doing something about it.” The new £5.14bn TV rights deal which kicks in next season means Premier League clubs will receive at least £100m for each of the next three years if they can avoid relegation. Attempts to introduce a cap on away tickets as a first measure of keeping prices down has so far failed to get off the ground after reluctance from some Premier League clubs. However, Harry Redknapp, who grew up watching Arsenal from Highbury’s North Bank, says it is now time for supporters to be respected. “The money that’s pumped in now through TV and players’ wages, managers’ wages, coaches’ wages, everybody’s having a slice of the pie,” he said. “The fans really should be getting the biggest slice, shouldn’t they? If there’s a bit to give out they should be helping the fans. It’s an expensive game for people with kids and having to go to football and it’s Saturday-midweek, Saturday-midweek. There are a lot of men out there working all week just to afford all their money going on taking the family to football. “I’m sure other clubs will be looking at that now. That will be a bit of a warning to them, this is what Liverpool fans are doing, they don’t want that. Even Liverpool called off a meeting on Monday night. They’ll do something about it, they’re not silly.” BT Sport has live football from the Champions League, Europa League, Premier League and the FA Cup.
